title.narrative: SNV 2019-2023: Fredlig gränsöverskridande boskapsskötsel i Sahel (MOPSS)
SNV 2019-2023: Peaceful cross-border pastoralism in the Sahel (MOPSS)

description.narrative: Copied from the Program Document dated 8 November 2019 and translated to English (the original results framework, in French, is copied further down): General and specific objectives: The overall goal of the program "Peaceful cross-border pastoral mobility and social stability in the Sahel" (Mobilité Pastorale transfrontalière apaisée et Stabilité sociale au Sahel; MOPSS) is to contribute to strengthening the resilience of agro-pastoral populations and social stability in the Sahel. To achieve this, three inter-connected and multi-level (regional, national, local) work streams are implemented to achieve the following specific objectives: 1. Strengthen the organizational governance of RBM and APESS, especially in its accountability and credibility dimensions. 2. Make the political and legal environment more favorable to the specificities of pastoralism. 3. Support the economic and social viability of pastoralism. The summarized detailed results framework, translated to English, looks as follows, numbered in reference to the specific objective it falls under: Expected results with regard to specific objective number 1: R1.1) The organizational structure and culture, in their membership and leadership dimensions, are strengthened in favor of the involvement of women and young people. R1.2) The capacities of analysis and influence of the members and the technical bodies are reinforced. R1.3) The provision of services to members and the capacity to collaborate with third parties are strengthened. R1.4) Administrative and financial management capabilities are improved. R1.5) Knowledge management capabilities are improved. Expected results with regard to specific objective number 2: R2.1) The revision and implementation of the policy and regulation of ECOWAS and its member states on livestock farming, pastoralism and transhumance integrate the views and feedback from the RPOs. R2.2) The coordination of interventions and the linkage of policies in the livestock sector in ECOWAS are improved. R2.3) The respect for the rights of pastoralists and agro-pastoralists is improved through piloting and testing a community based legal system. Expected results with regard to specific objective number 3: R3.1) Restrictions on mobility and market access are mitigated in cross-border areas. R3.2) The livelihoods of agro-pastoral family farms are maintained in trans-boundary areas. R3.3) The professional skills and employability of young people (boys and girls) in pastoral and agro-pastoral settings are strengthened. R3.4) The role of women and youth in promoting a culture of peace and social cohesion is strengthened. The original, summarized, results framework in French:

I detta beslut föreslås ett stöd om 42 miljoner kronor över c.a 1,5 år som ett första svenskt bidrag till ett tre-årigt program vid namn MOPSS, vilket syftar till att främja fredlig samexistens mellan i första hand boskapsskötare och jordbrukare i västra Sahel (Mali, Burkina Faso och Niger, men också Benin och Togo), och en samsyn på hur begränsade naturresurser såsom vatten, land och bete kan komma samtliga grupper till godo samt hur konflikter runt desamma kan förebyggas och lösas. Namnet MOPSS anspelar på programmets franska namn som fritt översatt till svenska är: "Fredlig gränsöverskridande rörlighet för boskapsskötare i Sahel och social stabilitet" (Mobilité Pastorale transfrontalière apaisée et Stabilité sociale au Sahel). Sidas inledande stöd begränsas av rådande bemyndiganderam (dvs det belopp Sida kan avtala för kommande år) men Sidas avsikt är att fortsätta stödja MOPSS även efter 2021 förutsatt att resultaten av den inledande fasen är goda samt att övriga omständigheter möjliggör detta.
Bakgrunden till insatsen är den kraftigt försämrade säkerhetssituationen i (västra) Sahel, den svenska regeringens beslut om att skjuta till ytterligare medel till den regionala strategin med fokus på mänsklig säkerhet i Sahel och det faktum att konflikter mellan boskapsskötare och jordbrukare visat sig lika dödlig som attackerna från beväpnade grupper samt att dessa olika konflikter därtill föder in i varandra på ett sätt som förefaller ytterligare späda på våldet och där boskapsskötande grupper inte bara tillhör de hårdast drabbade offren men också återfinns bland förövarna. Fokus ligger alltså på regionalt samarbete och gränsöverskridande utvecklingsutmaningar.
SNV föreslår under programmet MOPSS ett samarbete med boskapsskötarnas (APESS och RBM) och jordbrukarnas (ROPPA) egna regionala socio-professionella samarbetsorganisationer i Sahel / Västafrika, liksom stöd till samarbetsplattformar mellan dessa och andra berörda intressenter (Hub Rural). Även NGOn Care, med speciell erfarenhet från och expertis inom lokala rättssystem kopplat till boskapsskötares rättigheter ingår i konsortiet som leds av SNV och är Sidas avtalspart. SNV kommer att vidareförmedla knappt 30% av budgeten till övriga medlemmar i konsortiet.
Syftet med MOPSS är att:
1) stärka boskapsskötar-organisationernas (RBM och APESS) kapacitet att representera sina medlemmars intressen, men också deras interna demokrati och deltagande, med ett fokus på kvinnors och ungas speciella intressen och behov;
2) Påverka policy miljön och dess tillämpning, samt berörda regionala aktörer (med fokus på ECOWAS) att bättre tillgodose den rörliga gränsöverskridande boskapsskötselns behov;
3) Stötta social och ekonomisk uthållighet för gränsöverskridande, rörlig, boskapsskötsel, genom att bidra till nödvändig infrastruktur samt att stärka värdekedjor med koppling till boskapsskötsel, med ett speciellt fokus på kvinnor och ungas behov och inkomster.
Givet den försämrade säkerhetssituationen och den mycket föränderliga kontext som programmet ska genomföras i kommer SNV tillsammans med övriga medlemmar i konsortiet under en inledande fas om 8 månader genomföra ett antal studier för att identifiera i detalj vilka aktiviteter som ska och kan genomföras samt hur dessa ska följas upp och vilka konkreta resultat som är möjliga att nå. Efter denna inledande fas, som också syftar till att utforma och få på plats en projektorganisation, kommer Sida få ett uppdaterat resultatramverk och en uppdaterad budget och aktivitetsplan för genomförandet att ta ställning till. Därtill, givet fortsatt hög grad av oförutsägbarhet och osäkerhet, kommer Sida och SNV tilllsammans att anta former för löpande rapportering och justering av budget och aktivitetsplan för att anpassa programmet till den verklighet som råder, minimera och hantera risker, men samtidigt sträva efter att fortsatt bidra till stärkt mänsklig säkerhet och frihet från våld genom samarbete med boskapsskötarnas och jordbrukarnas egna organisationer.

This decision proposes a contribution of SEK 42 million over approximately 1.5 years as a first Swedish contribution to a three-year program called MOPSS, which aims to promote peaceful coexistence between primarily livestock farmers and sedentary farmers in the Western Sahel (Mali , Burkina Faso and Niger, but also Benin and Togo), and a strengthened consensus on how limited natural resources such as water, land and grazing can benefit all groups and how conflicts around them can be prevented and resolved. The name MOPSS refers to the French name of the program which is freely translated into English as follows: "Peaceful cross-border movement for livestock in the Sahel and social stability" (Mobilité Pastorale transfrontalière apaisée et Stabilité social au Sahel). Sida's initial support is limited by the current frame for outstanding commitments (i.e. the amount Sida can commit into the future), but Sida's intention is to continue supporting MOPSS even after 2021, provided that the results of the initial phase are good and that other circumstances allow for this.
The background to this proposed decision is the severely deteriorating security situation in (Western) Sahel, the Swedish government's decision to add funds to the Regional Strategy with a focus on human security in the Sahel, and the fact that conflicts between herders and farmers have proven as deadly as the attacks from armed groups, and that these various conflicts also feed into each other in a way that seems to increase violence and where herders not only belong to the most severely affected victims but also are found among perpetrators. Focus is therefore on regional cooperation and cross-border development challenges.
In the framework of the MOPSS program, SNV proposes to cooperate with the herders' (APESS and RBM) and the farmers' (ROPPA) own regional socio-professional organizations, as well as to support platforms for cooperation between them and other stakeholders (the Rural Hub). The NGO Care, with special experience and expertise from working with Community based justice systems linked to pastoral rights, is also a member of the consortium which is led by SNV who is also Sida's agreement partner.
The aim of MOPSS is:
1) strengthen the capacity of the herders' organizations (RBM and APESS) to represent the interests of their members, but also to strengthen their internal democracy and participation, with a focus on the special interests and needs of women and young people;
2) Influencing the policy environment and its application, as well as the relevant regional actors (with a focus on ECOWAS) to better meet the needs of mobile cross-border livestock farming;
3) Support the social and economic viability of cross-border, mobile, livestock farming by contributing to necessary infrastructure and promoting the value chains inked to livestock farming, with a special focus on women and young people.
Given the deteriorating security situation and the rapidly changing context in which the program is to be implemented, a number of studies will be carried out during an inception phase of 8 months to identify in detail which activities should and can be carried out, how they can be monitored and what concrete results are reachable. After the inception phase, which is also aims to put in place the program implementation organization, Sida will receive an updated results framework and an updated budget and activity plan for the implementation which will need to be assessed. In addition, given the continued high degree of unpredictability and insecurity, Sida and SNV will together adopt forms for continuous reporting and adjustment of the budget and activity plan to adapt the program to reality, minimize and manage risks, while at the same time strive to contribute towards improved human security and freedom from violence through cooperation with the herders and farmers' own organizations.

description.narrative: After the start-up phase that ended in August 2020, the program continued to implement activities in a context characterized by an increase in deadly attacks against civilians and the armed forces of Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger. Community conflicts and violent conflicts between farmers and herders persist in intervention areas. Also, the number of internally displaced populations (IDPs) caused by insecurity in Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger has increased dramatcally to almost 3 million in mid 2021. A 2020 study by one ot the partners (RBM) on insecurity and pastoralism provided evidence of the level of mistrust between pastors and defence and security forces and the motivations of pastors to take up arms. It also defined the bases of an exit strategy from pastoral and security crises. Whilst the fundamental right of pastoral mobility is recognized by the African Union, it is not sufficiently respected by member countries, particularly at the ECOWAS level. Some countries such as Burkina Faso and Mali have launched processes to review legal frameworks which govern livestock / pastoralism. The measures taken by the countries to limit mobility and close borders and markets in the face of the persisting Covid-19 pandemic have had several negative consequences on pastoralists / agro-pastoralists, in particular i) concentration of animals in certain localities which caused conflicts, ii) decline in animal sales and iii) difficult supply of feed and veterinary care products. The livelihoods of transhumant pastoralists have been impacted as the animals are transported on foot to livestock markets. The results obtained by the program so far are mainly on improving the governance of regional organisations, analysing the future of pastoralism in the Sahel, and improving the living conditions of pastoralists / agro-pastoralists: Financial managers of partners of the consortium have been trained on audit, internal control, and risk mapping. Thanks to program support, the administrative and financial management capacities of the partners of the consortium are improved and integrate conflict sensitivity and gender equality. APESS has set up functional national consultation spaces for young people and women in Benin, Niger, and Mali. With the support of the Peace Nexus Foundation and the program, RBM produced a document entitled "Influencing through Local Citizen Action (LCA): An original mode of action of the young ambassadors of pastoralism (YAP)". This document lays the methodological foundations for the implementation of LCA. As part of the capacity building of RPOs, six trainers including two women were trained in leadership. The trainers in turn trained twenty-four young leaders from Burkina Faso and Niger. MOPSS trained 49 people (21 women) on conflict-sensitive project management (CSPM). Implementation of the 2021 action plan will be focused on i) the dissemination of the results of the study on pastoralism and insecurity in pastoral areas in order to influence state policies, ii) training of legal actors on pastoral land rights, iii) leadership and governance of RPOs, iv) access and use of renewable energies by households, and v) socio-professional integration of young people (boys and girls) in the agro-pastoral environment.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
